title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO — On a night where offensive artistry gave way to defensive grit, one man’s historic performance stood as a monument to sheer force of will. While the final score read Indiana Pacers 93, San Antonio Spurs 78, the true story was written by Reggie Miller, who delivered a regular-season masterpiece for the ages.

Miller, the Pacers’ sinewy sharpshooter, detonated for a career-high and franchise-record 47 points, single-handedly outscoring the entire Spurs team through three quarters. His night was a blur of motion, a relentless pursuit of open space that ended with the ball ripping through the net. He was surgical from beyond the arc, connecting on five three-pointers, but it was his complete offensive onslaught—a perfect 14-of-14 from the free-throw line—that underscored his killer instinct.

The Spurs, simply, had no answer. David Robinson’s 22 points and 12 rebounds were a noble effort, but they were rendered secondary in the face of Miller’s historic outburst. Every Spurs run was met with a cold-blooded jumper from Miller, a drive into the lane, or a trip to the charity stripe. He was the Pacers' offense, their defense, and their undeniable heartbeat.

This was more than just a road win; it was a statement carved into the record books. In an era defined by physicality, Miller’s 47-point night was a testament to precision and perseverance, a performance so dominant it left the Alamodome in a state of stunned silence and secured his legacy as one of the game’s most lethal scorers.
